column1: ESFJ	I don't know that I can point to one or two specific people that I consider role models as much as I notice small things people do that I admire. I will notice a gesture of kindness or an act of selflessness someone does and then I'll try to incorporate that into the way I treat others as well. I admire people whose actions and words align and who are consistently a good person and aren't arrogant or pompous. I appreciate other people who work on being inclusive and considerate. In a leadership setting
column2: I appreciate those who are organized and give clear directions of their expectations and deadlines and know how to say thank you to their employees from time to time.

column1: ESFJ	Honesty
column2: loyalty
column3: kindness
column4: empathy
column5: selflessness
column6: organizational skills
column7: and humor are all character traits I admire.

column1: ESFJ	Originally Posted by SimplyEnigmatic   I'll get this thread started :P

column2: its people who are not frightened to stand up for others. People who aren't frightened/uncomfortable with confrontation (when it's being used for good).

column1: ESFJ	How often are you approached by someone new?
ESFJ	What are the most likely circumstances that you are approached?

ESFJ	These questions are confusing to me. Maybe that's because I feel like I interact and talk to all sorts of people on a daily basis. There pretty much isn't anyone I feel I can't chat up and somehow people come up to me and are comfortable talking to me too even if I don't really know them too well or just in passing. So I guess the answer would be I'm approached often by people I know and people on the outskirts of my circles. People who are absolute total strangers will sometimes greet me in passing going to the grocery store or chat me up in the post office in the waiting line or at a coffee shop trying to figure out what to order / kill time waiting in line. Or if I see another mom having a hard time with their toddler's tantrum somewhere
column2: I'll say a word of support to the mom and she'll start talking with me or something like that. I mean
column3: pretty much anywhere people are who need to fill time with small talk
column4: basically. Haha!

column1: ESFJ	I was trying to be quite general. I'm sorry for the confusion. Nevertheless
column2: the question is answered.

column1: ESFJ	If any clarification means anything
column2: I was talking about how often you get into conversations when you see someone around. Whether they be a stranger
column3: a friend etc.

ESFJ	Yes! This makes me so happy. More ESFJ representation please~
ESFJ	Originally Posted by SimplyEnigmatic   If you had to pick a life: one that never changes
column2: or one that constantly has unpredictable and everlasting changes. (I am talking about

column1: ESFJ	the extreme extremities). Consistent vs Volatile (for good or bad) lifestyles.

ESFJ	And why do you pick the one you chose?    I would pick the one that never changed. I want to believe in my head that I would pick the unpredictable / ever changing one because then I'd be adventurous and cool.... but in reality
column2: I would rather pick the never changing one. I will add one caveat though
column3: ONLY if the never changing one has good feelings. Like my family is happy and we're all in a good place. I actually find a lot of joy in things that other people would say are "mundane." I like hearing about my kids' day in school and catching up with a friend or just chilling with my husband after the kids are in bed. To me it's the little things that make a life.

column1: ESFJ	IRL we're about to make a big move to a new city and switch school for the kids and jobs etc. etc.... so it's honestly all very stressful to me and makes me feel some form of anxiety (even though I don't usually feel like an anxious person). I couldn't imagine feeling this way for eternity. It's horrible
column2: while exciting... it's just too much stress for me.

column1: ESFJ	Originally Posted by providence   What does your ideal day look like?    Wake up around 7am
column2: have breakfast with my family
column3: drop kids off at school
column4: go to yoga
column5: get some tea / coffee with a friend and catch up
column6: run errands / be productive getting things done
column7: get kids from school and chat with them about their day
column8: cook dinner with my husband and eat as a family
column9: put kids to bed and spend the rest of the night watching a show with my husband or meeting up with some of my girlfriends at their house. So I guess
column10: a pretty typical day where everything runs smoothly. (Yes
column11: of course I also would like days with more adventure built into them but if I'm honest with myself
column12: I like those to be reserved to vacation or a certain duration before returning to normal life)      Originally Posted by providence   What things in relationships make you the most happy?    Feeling like I'm in a committed and stable relationship where we both are doing our part working towards a common goal / values. I feel happy when the work I do at home or for our family is recognized (with words) and when my husband gives me undivided attention to hear my stories no matter how trivial they may be (obviously for my INTP husband this is a limited amount of time... but during that time I feel like he's truly listening and giving me his all). I feel happy when we're on the same page with life values and how we raise our kids and what's important to us as a family and when we work as a team towards those goals.

column1: ESFJ	So is it all really about "all the small details" such as my ESFJ's tell me on a daily?
ESFJ	Who notices all these "small details"?
ESFJ	Originally Posted by FueledByEvil   So is it all really about "all the small details" such as my ESFJ's tell me on a daily?
ESFJ	Who notices all these "small details"?    For one
column2: we notice. Haha! But that aside
column3: yes I do think it's important to us. I think it is what makes our world a kinder place. It's one way to show you care about people by doing small things for them. It's like life drums on at a basic level of busyness and anonymity but when somebody else on their own accord does some small act of kindness or remembers a small detail about you
column4: it can really turn someone's day for the better. I think it makes people feel like they matter and are noticed and not just swimming in a sea of people and work and jobs and busy life
column5: you know? Like it brings a little humanity back.

column1: ESFJ	For instance
column2: this week I noticed it was one of my kids' teachers birthday (via Facebook) and wished her a happy birthday that morning and my daughter decided on her own accord she wanted to make her a card. The teacher was really surprised and touched to read it and that someone would remember. I also wrote a friend (outer circles / acquaintance) of mine in town who is nearing the end of her pregnancy and told her I know how crazy it is at the end to find care for your other kids while you go into labor and I could definitely watch hers for her if she wants (our kids are in the same class etc). She was so relieved because she has no family in town and didn't know what else she would do. She never asked me or hinted on it but I just knew this would be a nice thing to help someone out. Or the other day in passing I told someone I know that I read his article he wrote for the student paper and thought it was wonderful and his face lit up and he was excited it reached other people and meant something to them. Just a few examples
column3: but you get the point.

column1: ESFJ	I think we ESFJs know that other people don't really do these little things a lot or really care to do them
column2: but I guess it's something we feel we can give to the world to meet people's needs before maybe they even know they have one. A simple "thank you" or a sign of appreciation can really make someone's day and it's not that hard to do and pay attention to the people around you. (Secretly or not so secretly if you're married to an ESFJ
column3: we hope that the people who love us will return the same kindness to us. We do a lot for the people we love in our families
column4: so many little things every day noticed and unnoticed
column5: so I guess we just "hope" that they will sometimes return the same thoughtfulness to us even though we understand that others aren't necessarily as good at it is as we are... it's the thought
column6: no wait
column7: the effort that counts)

column1: ESFJ	Originally Posted by Ashes4719   Ohh
column2: can I ask you about how you and your partner deal with arguments or disagreements? I am an ENFJ and my partner is an INTJ and we are so great together until an argument happens. Both of us are so bold headed we don't want to back down if that makes sense     Arguments? We never argue :-P

column1: ESFJ	Haha. I guess it depends on the argument. If it's something small
column2: then it'll usually start off a bit heated before ending in laughter with us poking fun at each other.

column1: ESFJ	If it's a BIG argument
column2: then the situation is very different. Typical ESFJ
column3: I HATE confrontation
column4: where as my partner will confidently take on literally anyone for an argument (which weirdly is one of things I massively admire about him when it's being used for a good cause). When this situation does happen it will normally result in me clamming up
column5: which unfortunately makes him even more heated because he thinks I'm just giving him the 'silent treatment' when I'm actually not. Rational goes out the window on both sides. We'll normally just go to different parts of the house until we've both calmed down
column6: and then afterwards we'll talk about it all rationally. Given we've been together 13 years at the end of this month
column7: this way of dealing with a 'big argument' must be working well for us if/and when one does happen haha.

column1: ESFJ	@Ashes4719
column2: dealing with arguments as an ESFJ married to an INTP is tricky sometimes. Fortunately
column3: we've been married for 10+ years now so it's gotten easier. He tries to split hairs on wordings of things and used to in the past try to make everything sound like it had to be totally logical (like emotions weren't valid arguments
column4: etc). Little things I just let go and for big things
column5: we found it's usually best for him to take some introverted alone time and cool down (even though I as an extrovert want to talk about it immediately... but that usually ends up badly so we've found over the years to just let the introvert go get some space for awhile then come back and talk). Once we reconvene to talk more calmly
column6: there are times in the past when I just back peddle and think in my head this isn't worth it and let's just get along again and move forward. Now I've gotten better at actually talking through things and not back peddling just to avoid conflict. He's gotten better at validating my feelings and realizing there's a "feeler logic" that may not always stack up with concrete facts etc. Without that realization
column7: it was hard at the way beginning of our relationship because I felt really misunderstood and he in return felt very frustrated by not understanding what was happening logically plus getting flooded by confusing emotions (mine and his).

column1: ESFJ	I think ENFJs might be different
column2: I don't know. But the ENFJ friend I know is much more out spoken and for lack of a better word "aggressive" in arguments and very stubborn. She makes me feel uncomfortable when she gets like that and makes me feel like she doesn't actually want to hear anyone else's perspective because she's so locked into her own and kind of "attacks" (although I don't think she sees it as that) people who speak up and differ from her viewpoint. I don't know if this is just me or an ESFJ thing but I feel like I keep pretty calm and while I can totally be stubborn too and think I'm right
column3: I'd rather have peace and calm than always be "right." In the end
column4: no one truly "wins" arguments in a relationship because you still have to live with this person forever so proving that you're "right" and being stubborn about it really only drives the other person away....which in the end hurts you because you want to have a good relationship with your partner and not just be the winner and alone. One of the many reasons I try to be careful with my wording during heated arguments is because I know at some point we'll make up again but I don't want to regret the words I've said because I truly love this person and want to have a harmonious family. And to be totally honest
column5: I expect more of myself and slumming it during fights makes me look bad to myself.

He totally knows what I mean but he likes to try and get me with the word choice which drives me up a wall. She makes me feel uncomfortable when she gets like that and makes me feel like she doesn't actually want to hear anyone else's perspective because she's so locked into her own and kind of "attacks" (although I don't think she sees it as that) people who speak up and differ from her viewpoint. I don't know if this is just me or an ESFJ thing but I feel like I keep pretty calm and while I can totally be stubborn too and think I'm right
column9: I'd rather have peace and calm than always be "right." In the end
column10: no one truly "wins" arguments in a relationship because you still have to live with this person forever so proving that you're "right" and being stubborn about it really only drives the other person away....which in the end hurts you because you want to have a good relationship with your partner and not just be the winner and alone. One of the many reasons I try to be careful with my wording during heated arguments is because I know at some point we'll make up again but I don't want to regret the words I've said because I truly love this person and want to have a harmonious family. And to be totally honest
column11: I expect more of myself and slumming it during fights makes me look bad to myself.    You made several great points! I don't know why but I have noticed that ENFJs do have a very strong opinion I guess you could say. I see it in myself and other ENFJs but I have really tried to work on it. Sometimes I just think something is right because to me its obvious and morally right even though to someone else it is not true for them. I think this can be part of the issues with the arguments I have had with my partner. He finds things very logical and it must be right because it's logical while I am on the other end saying it must be right because it makes others/me feel this way.

column1: ESFJ	I also agree with the point you made about always being "right". I know that is so stupid and immature but sometimes I do feel like that so I do definitely need to work on just trying to comprise since I do love this person and want to be with them.
ESFJ	Anyway
column2: just as a disclaimer
column3: I am not always arguing with my partner! I was re-reading my messages and was like oh my gosh I make it seem like I am in this unhappy relationship. I am very happy
column4: I just wanted opinions on how others dealt with arguments in relationships since they are bound to happen.

column1: ESFJ	@Ashes4719
column2: no worries! Never thought even for a second that you all argue a lot or anything like that. All people in relationships have disagreements and I read somewhere in some psychology paper that the way couples resolve these fights are more indicative of their future success than whether or not they ever have an argument.

column1: ESFJ	I'm not sure if this will help you with an INTJ
column2: but I have found with my INTP husband that I can't argue in his wheelhouse. Like anytime I would try to defend my side with pure logic and no emotion
column3: I immediately lose. There's just no logic on logic fighting with an INTP that I'm going to win. They'll always find that one word that you said that could be taken a different way. That was hard sometimes because I honestly didn't even remember what I said because it was more about the feelings behind the words than the actual dictionary definition. So then he felt like I was being evasive and changing my "story" when I would say I didn't remember saying those words or something like that. I wanted him to get the emotions and he wanted to get the words and we just talked right past each other into a world of hurt.

column1: ESFJ	What I've realized is that back then I felt sometimes like he should just "know" what I mean when I talk about feelings things (because it's SO obvious to me)
column2: but the truth is...he just didn't. Sometimes he needed to piece together the facts of the timeline of events before he could get to the emotions. And for me
column3: it's like I just want him to get why I'm so upset and the feelings involved and the rest of it doesn't matter. But now we've found a better way to talk about it. He tries to validate my feelings and I'll try to find ways to make things a little less emotionally charged or directed (he would totally just shut down and not even try to listen if he felt I was directing my emotional anger at him vs just wanting to be understood). He accepts now that there's a "feeler logic" and while it doesn't always make sense to him
column4: he know it's real and doesn't try to squash them anymore. And in return
column5: I try to realize that sometimes too many emotions are overwhelming for him and I'll try my best to stay calm and collected and not too stubborn. I focus more on being understood than setting out to "win."

column1: ESFJ	About the feeling like sometimes you just feel morally right
column2: I think that's something we all can feel sometimes. I used to think things were much more black and white than I do now. My husband has really helped among other things broaden my view on it. He once dissected in great detail the old "Golden Rule' that so many kids back in the day were taught about "treating others the way you'd like to be treated." At first I was like
column3: well of course. Makes sense. Good rule to live by. But then he was like but what if you're someone who enjoys being cat called because you like the attention and it makes you feel attractive
column4: do you get to just go treat others that way then too even if it may make them uncomfortable? Obviously there are many other examples. The point being
column5: we don't know what's best for others. So our "moral rightness" may work for us but may not necessarily be right for anyone else so when we hold this up high and use it as a grounds to fight all scorched earth
column6: it really just weakens our relationships and makes us less open minded. I've also been around a few *STJs who are older and hold on firmly to their "rightness" and man
column7: it makes them just look very closed off to the world and embittered. I really don't want to end up that way just so on my deathbed I can say "Ah ha! I was right! See everyone!"....  What's the point of that?

column1: ESFJ	Anyway
column2: hope some of that made sense. Enjoyed reading your posts!

column2: hope some of that made sense. Enjoyed reading your posts!    Yes
column3: your input has totally helped! I am so glad I read these posts and asked if anyone else had any ways to get through arguments with their SO. I also have tried to logically argue with him but it never works so I will try to just explain in my point of view. I just have tried to bridge that gap but the same thing will happen with me. ESFJ	As an NT in a 20 year relationship with a Feeler (ESFJ).
ESFJ	As well as a 24 year old ESFJ son.
ESFJ	Logic sucks. Rational actors we are not. Its fun to think about.
ESFJ	It can help and indeed can make for some level headed arguments.
ESFJ	That said. Almost all decisions made by humans are based off of
ESFJ	emotion and feelings.
ESFJ	Never give up on pushing your morals and one sided feelings.
ESFJ	I am not saying be pig headed. Just be clear. Your feelings and the recognition
ESFJ	of how they effect you and your choices are far more important then the
ESFJ	rational actor bit. If we are going to logic the shit out of items? Great!
ESFJ	Schedules dealing with finances work  ect ect ... yet those items
ESFJ	are tangible. They are measurable. The only argument would be how much
ESFJ	or how little. Pretty easy. Most arguments between my wife and I are not
ESFJ	about logical/rational items. They are about how we FEEL about happenings
ESFJ	in our lives.
ESFJ	I guess what I am getting at is this here..... Was it important for my ESFJ to
ESFJ	understand that I may argue logic all the time? Yes. What was more important is that
ESFJ	I realized that logic is not love. Logic is not life. Logic fails me when my heart hurts.
ESFJ	Logic fails me when my son is sick
column2: logic failed me when my brother died
column3: logic failed

column1: ESFJ	me when I felt betrayed. Logic for all its goodness should be taken into consideration

column1: ESFJ	Originally Posted by SimplyEnigmatic   I don't get approached at all. I prefer places with not as much social activity. And the fact that I am a male doesn't help either. ESFJ	I'm always thinking so I think that gives off a distant vibe. Which can be off putting to some people (?). I just know I have this calming energy around me.
ESFJ	Initially
column2: quite calmly. Leading with a "Hows it going?" or "Hows life?". My later response is heavily reliant on the topic the person picked. But generally people pick great topics. It ranges from explosiveness (incredibly rare) to downright uninterest. If I had to pick a general trend: choosing a movie that you are uncertain of and then enjoying the movie.

column1: ESFJ	I have an INTP friend that is ridiculously smart
column2: but always doubts herself.  She will be 51 this year but has always taken the "easy" route with gainful employment so that she can pursue her other interests.  She was never interested in ambition or the rat race.  When she got laid off a few years ago
column3: her choices were obvious:  either take some shit job somewhere
column4: or go to university and get her degree.  She has been going to school a few years now and is working toward her MFA.  She thinks that she would like to teach at the university level eventually but is afraid of failure.  I have reassured her about 4521545133 times that she'll do fine NOT because she is organized (she is not)
column5: but because it's obvious that she takes a great deal of interest in the subject matter and actually WANTS to impart that knowledge to others.

column1: ESFJ	Coming from an ESFJ
column2: I had a hard time saying no for the longest time until recently because of my relationship with an ex who was ISTP. I learned a lot from him and he taught me what I needed for myself and deserved in a relationship
column3: which meant that I definitely needed to date an N person haha. I used to say "Maybe" as a way to avoid conflict of saying no and feeling bad. column5: which is why I was so intrigued with your responses. They felt relatable in a way
column6: but I see that I have to use my Ti in moderation to be balanced enough with my Fe dom. The ESFJ you were talking to probably was just unaware and more unhealthy if anything. Not all ESFJs are that way

column1: ESFJ	I secretly don't like hosting people or throwing kid's birthday parties at our house. I put way too much pressure on myself for the house to look perfect and have the food be something everyone likes plus having to get all 3 little kids dressed decently and myself and then be like the fun hostess. It's just a lot. Then the whole time I'm also thinking about if everyone's enjoying themselves or what can make people more comfortable etc. Just a lot of work and then the house is a wreck afterwards...even though I feel I've been cleaning after people all day. I much rather have friends who are super outgoing and love to host and then go to their events. Lol! Way less pressure and more fun!
ESFJ	(I also don't like picking out the background music because I don't know what type of music everyone likes... I totally overthink it. lol! I'm sure no one would ever know that from the outside)

column2: broken
column3: shattered

column6: and what they need to do to change it. The advice usually involves them sucking up their self pity and growing a pair of fat fucking balls.

column1: ESFJ	Next.

If a group of people is smiling dancing having a great time and need me to oblige and partake in order to preserve the social atmosphere I will stubbornly refuse and sit there stone cold and non-participating no matter what
column3: even if that means ruining it for everyone else there.

column1: ESFJ	Ok Here is a little bit about me. I don't have a lot of social experience (sheltered childhood and other stuff.) I have an extremely introverted mother and an extremely extroverted father. (He is so gregarious and sociable he can't tell when he is irritating someone or if someone is making fun of him.) My father gets on my nerves all the time because he draws too much attention to us in public. I have no problem with casual conversation with strangers but like to keep it short unless I know them well. I tend to always do the right thing when inwardly seething about when is it my turn to be loved
column2: appreciated
column3: etc until I get my fill and I blow up in a tearful FE mess about how no one ever cares about me
column4: loves me

column6: etc (it is quite a pathetic sight) Then I feel ashamed and the process starts over. I get very irritated when I am in the middle of something and someone interrupts. column2: realize that he will need space. He will have thoughts and feelings that he will need to process on his own before sharing them. This doesn't mean he doesn't like/trust/love you. It's just a different way of processing things. This is one of the things I'm talking about by true needs: the need for space.    I can definitely understand that. Some of the major disconnects between my wife and I are her impatience (generally and with the time it takes for me to process things) and her temper (as is said often across the web
column3: ESFJs are ones to hold grudges; this clashes with my tendency to forgive and forget.) My biggest problems handling an ESFJ include her biggest needs -- her need to be loved
column4: needed
column5: and appreciated. I don't naturally exude these things. It takes a lot of energy (that I don't often have after handling her people problems and my work problems).

column1: ESFJ	Originally Posted by NannyMercy4   That is very insightful.  I understand the INTJ's need for space.  Each person has their own way of dealing with things.  So It makes sense to try to be thoughtful of everyone's different needs and ways of doing things.  However
column2: I think people need to leave room for people of the same personality to have different tendencies.  Like take an ESFJ
column3: they can have similar tendencies
column4: and yet each one has been raised differently and so will react differently than other ESFJ's.  Not to discount what you are saying
column5: I understand what you are saying
column6: I mean I couldn't live with an INTP.  Although
column7: I try to leave room for different people to enter into my life
column8: and not discount them just because of their personality.    It sounds like you have a pretty healthy handle on the situation.

column2: you have to call everybody you know and tell them about it.

column2: you have to call everybody ELSE you know and make sure they hear about it.

column1: ESFJ	5. You watch the weather channel
column2: and keep everybody in the family informed of travel conditions.

column1: ESFJ	6. You make big dinners sometimes just so you can invite people over.

column2: then feel bad because you made them cry.

column1: ESFJ	8. Whenever you find a funny video
column2: you try to get everybody else in the house to come and watch it with you.

column1: ESFJ	9. You get so mad at your ex you swear you will never speak to her again

column2: you try to come up with a logical excuse for why you are upset.

column1: ESFJ	11. You will take things way too far

column1: ESFJ	12. You fish for compliments unabashedly.

ESFJ	Both of my parents are ESFJ's and it was hell growing up. I actually rebelled so bad against them when I was a teenager that they  sent me to boarding schools to finish highschool. I think they saw it as punishment but it was a godsend. I felt very misunderstood growing up. My Mom constantly criticised me about my clothes and the way I looked and was extremely invasive and controlling. She read my journals
column2: never let me lock my door. Actually I don't think I was even allowed to keep the door closed. My Dad was always asking me why I didn't have many friends or why I wasn't in cheerleading? Very status and image conscious. He made me join coitillion because "manners/social skills never go out of style." He thought I was a weird kid and this would miraculously turn me into a pretty little princess. It was basically torture. I was kicked out the second week because a boy asked me to dance and we were supposed to be lady like and curtsy. I was like
column3: "I'm sorry dude
column4: fuck off Im not going to curtsy
column5: this is stupid."  I actually feel bad for that kid now that I think of it
column6: because I had nothing against him. But the whole idea of coitillion was absurd.

ESFJ	I literally went through this whole chat
column2: there are a lot of things I personally don't connect with... For example I'm not a person who likes to share a whole lot.. A lot of times when someone asks me whats wrong
column3: most of the time I'm not sure how I feel. It takes me awhile to open up to new people and speaking infront of people makes me panic a little. I always feel amazing after.. But I always have a nervous breakdown inside my head before speaking in public. I very much enjoy being around people and observing what people do or what they say. I usually do a good job analyzing it in my head but if someone asks me what I think I'm usually not very good at sharing. I get hurt a lot by friends and guys I date mostly bbecause I expect a lot and I'm somewhat naieve about the world and how things are. It's super hard for me to hear bad things about people and it usually effects me pretty deeply. When people are sad around me I feel very bad and when I'm around happy people I'm happy. I usually panic when I don't have things planne out in advanced and when things don't operate smoothly I stress a lot. I care very deeply for people... Sometimes too deeply and I get hurt. At times I can be overly emotional and assume something too quickly and stress out about something that ends up being nothing. When people are mean
column4: I just can't understand it.. And if they are mean to me I sometimes feel so hurt I try and hurt them back which ends up making me feel even more sad and then I seem crazy because I'm apologizing.. Lately I've been hurt so much by people and then I go back to them apologizing for this or that when THEY should be apologizing to me.. Why do we do that? I constantly am bending over backwards instead of standing up for myself. I let my guard down too quickly because I truly believe the best in people and most of the time I get hurt! Ahhhh the life of an ESFJ!!! I struggle very often with the thought of people not liking me and being upset with me.. I take it so personally

column1: ESFJ	You know you're an ESFJ when:
ESFJ	1. You find out that a lot of people don't generally like ESFJs and that bothers you.
ESFJ	2. You often feel misunderstood and are compelled to explain how you feel about it.
ESFJ	3. You're an author/writer who writes historical fiction and your novels are character driven and not plot driven.
ESFJ	4. Music has be melodious for you to like it.
ESFJ	5. You have trouble getting along with people who "over think" things.
ESFJ	6. You get impatient with people who have a hard time making decisions.
ESFJ	7. You are quite literal.
ESFJ	8. People don't realize you're as talented and/or intelligent as you really are and often treat you as if you're stupid.
ESFJ	9. History was your favorite subject in school.
ESFJ	10. You actually enjoy teaching.
ESFJ	11. You follow the rules and get mad at those who "cheat".
ESFJ	12. You were the one who got in trouble the most in school for talking and/or whispering in class.
ESFJ	13. You are always the one standing up for the under dog.
ESFJ	14. You love movies
column2: books
column3: tv shows
column4: etc. that make you cry.

column1: ESFJ	15. You prefer sad endings to happy ones.
ESFJ	16. You enjoy giving presents more than getting them.
ESFJ	17. You get offended when your spouse gives you practical gifts for Christmas
column2: anniversaries
column3: and birthdays
column4: over sentimental or personal ones.

column1: ESFJ	18. You get offended when you've worked hard all day cleaning and vacuuming the house
column2: and all your spouse notices is the cob webs in the corner that you didn't get.

column1: ESFJ	19. You don't get sick very often
column2: but when you do
column3: you're really sick and no one takes you seriously and/or they think you're faking it.

column3: you're harder on yourself than they are.

column1: ESFJ	I think we make people uncomfortable because we give them undivided attention
column2: and can easily overwhelm or annoy them with our hyper-focusing. We also hunt people like heat-seeking missiles; no one wants to feel like they're under the radar all the time
column3: especially introverts. We can also be a bit invasive and excessively outgoing at times
column4: which can be equally overwhelming.

column1: ESFJ	We have surface relationships because we dive into people much too quickly
column2: get bored
column3: then slip away. Sometimes it's because we don't realize that we distance ourselves until we run into the person again
column4: during which we act as if nothing has changed and welcome them back
column5: and even convince them that we missed them terribly. We distance ourselves because these relationships mean nothing to us; we don't actually feel close to that person because we aren't. People are our priority
column6: but the mystery in people we don't know is ever-tempting. Once we satisfy that curiosity
column7: they can become rather uninteresting and we jump to the next stimulus.

column1: ESFJ	Also
column2: we think more about shaping ourselves around other people and the idea of being a good 'friend' to them
column3: completely forgetting the importance of authenticity in forming long-standing relationships. And this is because we understand people so well. We are able to know things about them very quickly
column4: and then decide quickly how we feel about them. I think the problem isn't  lack of understanding
column5: but a lack of truthfulness. We care more about being pleasant and liked than being actually close to people
column6: which will lead to our general dissatisfaction with our personal relationships. Our understanding of people is usually unspoken
column7: because it's something we've become used to
column8: and sometimes use as a tool for manipulation (bad trait #3). It's also an extremely difficult thing to explain. Usually we're too busy taking action in response to what we sense about a person

column4: enlightened person. column1: ESFJ	I used to try to be

column1: ESFJ	Speaking of the disaster...it was an unfortunate moment on Google chat where three people happened to engage me all at once. To me that is essentially like trying to change masks very quickly. I have to remember the specific frame I use for each person
column2: the mindset
column3: and implement all three at the same time. What happened was similar to a machine that's overheated and comically starts to shake and steam and then subsequently explodes. I can't jump between skins so rapidly; I like to take time to process the conversation with each person
column4: because for each I'm following a specific stream of consciousness. I'm thinking in and around each of them individually
column5: and it takes a lot of focus.

column1: ESFJ	It didn't help that I was talking theory with one
column2: emotionally consoling another
column3: and was particularly nervous about speaking with the third. Three things that should not mix. It was like I had three voices in my head and each was telling me to do something different. My sister was in the room and she mentioned that she had never seen me reach a point at which I was socially overwhelmed (given the amount of energy I normally have for it). I think I just closed my computer and flopped on the floor for a while.

column1: ESFJ	I realized from this that my social energy is expended in rations
column2: with exceptional endurance (the interaction vids are a good example of this) so long as there is one point of focus. Handling group situations is a matter that I approach differently.

ESFJ	Hi Steelight! So great you're coming at it with a "trying to understand" mindset. I appreciate all you've said. I think in the end everything is relative and just as ESFJs may seem difficult to you (and some other types here) to communicate with
column2: I would say the same could be said in reverse for Feelers to Thinkers. Being married to an INTP
column3: I completely understand how these miscommunications happen but I've also seen how these can be mitigated in the future and resolved in a respectful way to each personality type. There is no one best personality type and I would venture to speculate that there is no one type that is the most difficult to talk to (objectively) if you remove your own personality bias / lens with which you see the world.

column1: ESFJ	Regarding your close friend
column2: I'm sure if you wrote down some of the conflicts we could help you see where the breakdown happened. ESFJs biggest strength is Extroverted Feeling and our biggest weakness is Introverted Thinking. So if you approach a conflict with your ESFJ friend from only a pure logic (in the T sense of the word) then you're trying to tap into their weakest function in their moment of stress. Sometimes I think T types can equate feelings = weakness / irrationality and logic = rightness and I don't think that that helps in these situations or that it's fair to Feeler types. Perhaps next time when a miscommunication happens see if you can try to tap into the feelings side more and instead of saying something like "I don't get why you're so mad. That's clearly not what I was saying when I said xyz (**insert cold hard facts**)".... instead you might get further if you say something like "I can tell that this really hurt your feelings. I'm really sorry if something I said upset you. Why don't we talk it out a bit to figure this out." Basically validating that feelings have a place and while it probably won't make much sense to a T
column3: we do have a form of "feelings logic." Like any communication with personality types that are different than you (especially T & F) it requires you to go out of your comfort zone and see things from someone else's perspectives instead of trying to bring your own logic to the table. Next time ask yourself: Where is this miscommunication coming from? What is my role in it? Was I (inadvertently) trying to crush feelings with logic? Did I validate their feelings and allow them space to honor their personality stacking? How can resolving miscommunication with other personality types help me grow as a person / help develop my weaker functions?

column1: ESFJ	Think about your weakest function and imagine someone always just wanted you to use that to resolve conflicts. Sometimes ESFJs don't want solutions and logical banter / dissection. Sometimes we just want to feel heard and our feelings be validated. Once those settle we're usually much more open to discussing things in a more "rational" way.

column3: Te the rider.

column1: ESTJ	Ne's brainstorming process guided and condensed by Te into a final
column2: best solution. Te doesn't come up with the various ideas; it simply identifies the best from among the many. Si confirms or confronts Te's conclusion
column3: and Fi justifies it or condemns it morally.

column1: ESTJ	For example
column2: say you asked me to think of ways to smuggle a knife into a prison.

column1: ESTJ	Ne creates the various possibilities (smuggle it baked in bread
column2: put it in a book with a cutout in the pages
column3: deliver through a corrupt guard
column4: fly it by drone over the prison walls).

column1: ESTJ	Te refines the possibilities (bread probably gets screened
column2: book's already been done
column3: guard leaves a witness).

column1: ESTJ	Si confirms or denies Te's results.
ESTJ	Fi justifies or condemns the final solution (Harry really needs that knife to fight off his prison enemies).
ESTJ	Note: In this scenario
column2: Te would normally go first and ask "is smuggling the knife in even feasible?" or details like "what kind of prison/how many guards/what kind of security/etc" but this is a hypothetical and I'm pretending that I'm required to answer.

column1: ESTJ	I get burnt out spending too much time with people. I'm not much of one for initiating hanging out with others

column1: ESTJ	My social life tends to be pretty segregated too
column2: like I've got friends I hang out with in groups because it's fun and we can party
column3: then I have the friends I hang out with one on one or maybe 3 of us (who are usually my closer friends)
column4: there's acquaintances... People I know through organizations I'm a member or volunteer with that I only see there
column5: classmates (99% of them I don't hang out with outside of school) and workmates (same deal).

column1: ESTJ	Among the people I wouldn't hang out with outside of where we met
column2: I can apparently appear pretty reserved and uninterested in forming stronger relationships... it's not intentional
column3: but it pretty much is how I feel so I guess that works out.

I just want to understand you guys more and the only ESTJs i know are not healthy ones :/ So do any of you care about others? Are open minded and willing to be patient as well? What do you think of NFs? INFP
column2: INFJ
column3: ENFJ
column4: ENFP you know. What bothers you
column5: what are you okay with? I have high standards for people who are around me and i talk with so it may be me as well but I just want to know if any of you are willing to come out of your comfort zone and such? O.o    I can't speak for all ESTJs. I can be nice and kind
column6: but only when I'm not bothered by something. I try to be as patient and understanding as possible for me. Sincere
column7: not all the time. But when I am
column8: you feel it. At least that's what it seems like when I see people react to me.

column1: ESTJ	Do not give affection to people that do not give back unless doing so gets you something you appreciate other than being reciprocated.
ESTJ	I do care for others. Too much I think sometimes.
ESTJ	I am open minded because I want to hear your side of things. I want to understand you. So I listen. However
column2: it would appear that I am not because I'm most likely going to disagree with a lot of what you are doing. ^_____^

column1: ESTJ	Originally Posted by Miyu   How can you tell the difference between ESTJs and ISTJs?    Ask yourself which one is more likely to run you over if you stand in their way. That's the ESTJ. ISTJs are much more cautious and self-doubting
column2: and tend to far more passive. Three of my best friends are ISTJs- they're extremely organized
column3: but they aren't much good at organizing other people. ESTJs motivate groups and organize projects
column4: while ISTJs motivate themselves and organize themselves. As they grow older
column5: many ISTJs do learn how to work with groups
column6: but their natural preference is only a few people
column7: while ESTJs like a much larger group to work with
column8: and will often take a leadership role. I'm an ENTJ
column9: and the ESTJs I know appear far more extraverted than I am. Last week my ESTJ friend and I went shopping
column10: and she brought four of our other friends with us when I thought it would just be the two of us. ISTJs are far more likely to just go with the flow and follow along unless something is really wrong. They conserve their energy more.      Originally Posted by Whitewolf   Hi everyone! column1: ESTJ	How was your life between the age of about... 1 to 12 in general? Where there any specialy instances that seemed Te to you? How was your interaction with other children? How curious were you? How did you complete your tasks and how did you do at school? What were your hobbies and are there any interesting things that you want to mention?

ESTJ	To give an example for the last one: I used to "bake" a lot of "cakes" when I was 4 or 5. I just threw together things that could theoretically be made into a cake and added other ingredients that I wanted to have in it. Then
column2: I just baked it and was always happy that I created something
column3: although they were hardly ever edible.

column1: ESTJ	Also
ESTJ	@TopCatLSD
column2: if he wants ^^

column1: ESTJ	Originally Posted by Tsubaki   Also
ESTJ	@TopCatLSD
column2: if he wants ^^    Man
column3: I was a fuckin idiot when I was a kid. My parents used too worry about my health a lot.

column1: ESTJ	When I was a baby still sleeping in the crib
column2: my parents had given me my own room and put me right next to the window. Apparently I used to climb out of the crib and onto the window sill and stare outside
column3: my parents found me dangling my feet out the window trying to escape (<thanks mom & dad) I did it so often that they eventually gave my room to my sis and made me sleep in their room so they could supervise me. When I was little I also had a habit of hiding in my house until my parents would cry cause they thought they lost me
column4: then I'd burst out like "SURPRISE BITCH!!"

column1: ESTJ	When I started going to school
column2: I was constantly one of the most obnoxious kids in the class room. I was constantly making noise and trying to make my classmates laugh. My teachers hated me. Looking back I was probably a huge disappointment to me ESFJ dad
column3: he always wanted us to be the most successful out of everyone in our peer group
column4: but I would fail every academic subject and couldn't for my life concentrate in the classroom. I was also really possessive of girls I had crushes on (I think I still am
column5: actually) if I saw any guy talking to them
column6: I'd jump in and be like "Uh
column7: no bitch! She's mine."

column1: ESTJ	My 12 year old life was probably the darkest point in my life. I was part of an underground fight club with me and my main group of friends. I was cool with the skater table
column2: the black table
column3: and the beaner table <well
column4: the NOT as ghetto beaner table. (I'm hispanic
column5: I can say that). We used to get like thirty people at a time to show up and watch our fights
column6: it was so much fun. We used to plan fights like a day ahead of time and text out witch bathroom or hallway we where going to host it in. My job was to "charm" the campus supervisors into letting us go into the most empty parts of school
column7: I'd say "We need to go to Mr.Whatshisfaces room
column8: we'll be quick" or my favorite "Oh campus supervisor #2 I almost didn't notice you got your hair done
column9: it looks nice!" Cause there was so many of us
column10: we had to brake into squads and use different paths to get their
column11: my squad always had the easiest getting in. We also had a Youtube channel where we would post the fights
column12: but it got taken down by the cops...

column1: ESTJ	After that was over I got to go home to my bipolar INFP mum whom I was living with; I'll spare the details. My parents where going through divorce
column2: so all she could afford was a broken down piece of shit house with cockroaches and a falling roof. She would come home every night sobbing her eyes out
column3: depressed. It was my responsibility to care for her emotionally. It felt like I was parenting her
column4: and not the other way around. I legit feel sorry for any parents who have INFP kids
column5: It's absolutely miserable.

column1: ESTJ	^So if you're noticing a trend
column2: I was an incredibly Se heavy kid who grew up in an Ne-Fe heavy world.

column1: ESTJ	I usually had heaps of new ideas as a kid and I also liked to show them to other people. I managed to get many introverts very excited when they were playing with me. Being alone was also fine for me
column2: though. I always did some crazy things like creating my own vending machine that gives out marbles (as far as I remember
column3: I got several things stuck in the radiator when doing this) and I mixed together every kind of soap and shampoo that I found
column4: hoping that something cool would happen. I was also really energetic and happy at that time. My great-grandpa once told my grandma: "This kid isn't able to walk normally." She asked why he thought that and he responded: "She takes two steps and every third one is a jump" I remember that I was always very interested in science and my dad teached me how electricity works and gave me plugboards with all sorts of stuff to experiment with. I also had a book about it but I usually just tried my own stuff. (I also had a chemistry set and I tried to grow crystals for some time)

column1: ESTJ	I hated my kindergarden because the people were boring and never let me do what I wanted. The girls weren't very nice although I had a few female friends and I just liked to play with some of the boys. Also
column2: I frequently threw tantrums at that age because I was indecisive and someone forced me to decide. During elementary school
column3: I had two very good friends and also got along with the rest of the class. Our school was a bit alternative and we were able to do whatever we wanted whenever we wanted as long as we finished everything until the end of the day.

column1: ESTJ	I was at an after-school care club for one year and I totally hated it because of the same reasons
column2: I hated kindergarden. I usually just played with an ENTJ girl who was pretty bossy and sometimes hard to cope with.

column1: ESTJ	The start of middle school wasn't hard for me in terms of school work but there was one girl that heavily bullied another girl. I was in a rather introverted phase but I still decided to call her out for it - I don't even know why... Then
column2: that girl also tried to make me look bad which was just... kind of irritating but I didn't really care.

column1: ESTJ	My parents got divorced when I was 13 or something and it really hurt me
column2: although I didn't show it. For almost a year
column3: I sucessfully hid it
column4: just because I didn't want pity from anyone. In addition to that
column5: my ENFJ mum wanted to make everything more structured and started to give me restrictions.(I was able to decide almost everything on my own before that and it worked) I fought a lot with her and I often got into even worse situations because it's hard to discuss with someone who isn't willing to listen to other opinions.

column1: ESTJ	Since the start of highschool
column2: I'm more open again and I made lots of friends. I also think that I can cope with emotions way better now ^^

column1: ESTJ	Since the start of highschool
column2: I'm more open again and I made lots of friends. I also think that I can cope with emotions way better now ^^    Copy that
column3: here we go. (I'm probably going to include some stuff after 12/13 as well
column4: as it's relevant to the story.

column1: ESTJ	For a starter
column2: I wanted to know how everything worked. And I wanted to know the reason why I had to do stuff. (This one was important
column3: though it didn't really work well with ESFJ mother). Say why I had to eat with both fork and knife
column4: if I don't use the knife
column5: why would I have to have it in my hand? Why do I have to take of my shoes when it's dry outside and they aren't dirty? Why can't I go outside with just socks if they don't get dirty? I wanted answers on all of those questions
column6: and I wanted the answers to make sense
column7: so it really frustrated me when I got the answer "that's how you do it" or answers similar to that.

column1: ESTJ	Another problem that arose is rather connected to inferior Fi than Te
column2: but still. The general thing is that I wasn't always considerate to how other people would perceive what I was saying
column3: so they got hurt. Best example I can think of is ones when my sister had a new cap
column4: and well
column5: I didn't think it fit her. So I told her so. She took it badly
column6: and yea. My mom tried to explain to me that I shouldn't do stuff like that
column7: but I just told her what I thought as a matter of fact.

column1: ESTJ	I didn't really have any problem in school
column2: until I was about 11/12. Before that I enjoyed it
column3: I was good at what we did
column4: I learnt stuff (I've always wanted to learn interesting things
column5: though I have a hard time putting down the energy and time if I don't enjoy it or find it useful
column6: from when I was young 'til this day)
column7: and had lots of friends. After that though
column8: we started having English as a "real" subject
column9: (which didn't work out for me until maybe 14/15
column10: where I went from lowest to among the highest grades)
column11: and I "noticed" that I didn't really have any friends. Well
column12: I had friends to hang out with in school
column13: but I guess that's where my Fi went in and said that that wasn't enough
column14: and I wanted "more" than just that. So during the latter half of elementary school
column15: I went through without having any real friends.

column1: ESTJ	Later (13/14
column2: but relevant as I started developing my Te more here (I think))
column3: I used to get in to a lot of fights with my mom
column4: and looking at it from now
column5: I see that it's mostly Te/Fe. (also just teenager/parent
column6: but influenced by the functions) As I always wanted things to make sense
column7: and she didn't give me a reason for things but still forced them upon me

column1: ESTJ	I haven't had any problems with other kids in my age that I can think of. And Te wasn't that obvious either. Probably since I was raised in a very non-Te way by my ENFP dad and ESFJ mom. I was always taking the more submissive part in relations I entered
column2: which I didn't always like
column3: but that's how I worked at that time
column4: so that's what I did.

column1: ESTJ	When I was between five and about 12
column2: most of my spare time was spent outside
column3: making swords of sticks and wood and bow and arrow
column4: and then playing with those in a made-up world. Sometimes
column5: I could even stop playing for half an hour or so
column6: just to think of the back-story of who I was
column7: the world around him
column8: etc. I've always enjoyed making things myself
column9: and have a couple of padded swords I made just half a year ago
column10: for more "realistic" fighting. So I guess that interest has always been there

column1: ESTJ	Another thing I loved was Lego
column2: and making things myself (not according to the design
column3: but how I wanted it to be).

column1: ESTJ	Another thing that might be of interest is that when I became old enough to start helping with cleaning the house and stuff
column2: I pretty fast came to the conclusion that I had to have the responsibility for some part of it
column3: as it didn't work when my parents said "do this
column4: do that".

column1: ESTJ	I think I was less typical Te than I am now
column2: though it was there
column3: hidden underneath. I just wasn't comfortable to expose it until I changed school (elementary school wasn't that good
column4: and people weren't accepting of Te at all...)

ESTJ	I usually had heaps of new ideas as a kid and I also liked to show them to other people. I managed to get many introverts very excited when they were playing with me. Being alone was also fine for me
column2: though. I always did some crazy things like creating my own vending machine that gives out marbles (as far as I remember
column3: I got several things stuck in the radiator when doing this) and I mixed together every kind of soap and shampoo that I found
column4: hoping that something cool would happen. I was also really energetic and happy at that time. My great-grandpa once told my grandma: "This kid isn't able to walk normally." She asked why he thought that and he responded: "She takes two steps and every third one is a jump" I remember that I was always very interested in science and my dad teached me how electricity works and gave me plugboards with all sorts of stuff to experiment with. I also had a book about it but I usually just tried my own stuff. (I also had a chemistry set and I tried to grow crystals for some time)

column1: ESTJ	I hated my kindergarden because the people were boring and never let me do what I wanted. The girls weren't very nice although I had a few female friends and I just liked to play with some of the boys. Also
column2: I frequently threw tantrums at that age because I was indecisive and someone forced me to decide. During elementary school
column3: I had two very good friends and also got along with the rest of the class. Our school was a bit alternative and we were able to do whatever we wanted whenever we wanted as long as we finished everything until the end of the day.

column1: ESTJ	I was at an after-school care club for one year and I totally hated it because of the same reasons
column2: I hated kindergarden. I usually just played with an ENTJ girl who was pretty bossy and sometimes hard to cope with.

column1: ESTJ	The start of middle school wasn't hard for me in terms of school work but there was one girl that heavily bullied another girl. I was in a rather introverted phase but I still decided to call her out for it - I don't even know why... Then
column2: that girl also tried to make me look bad which was just... kind of irritating but I didn't really care.

column1: ESTJ	My parents got divorced when I was 13 or something and it really hurt me
column2: although I didn't show it. For almost a year
column3: I sucessfully hid it
column4: just because I didn't want pity from anyone. In addition to that
column5: my ENFJ mum wanted to make everything more structured and started to give me restrictions.(I was able to decide almost everything on my own before that and it worked) I fought a lot with her and I often got into even worse situations because it's hard to discuss with someone who isn't willing to listen to other opinions.

column1: ESTJ	Since the start of highschool
column2: I'm more open again and I made lots of friends. I also think that I can cope with emotions way better now ^^    Reading this
column3: it's a wonder how you ever managed to mistype as an ESTJ.

column3: and this is not an ESTJ thing so don't worry on types. I think she would be hurt but I also think if she was healthy she would accept it and still share how much she will miss you and be hurt by you wanting to leave and leaving. This has NOTHING to do with you

column7: like it's just a tool and the "real me" is something else.

column1: ESTJ
ESTJ			   I am acutely aware of my physical self; I don't pay attention to it in the day-to-day
column2: but it grabs my attention immediately when something is not right. I know exactly where my pains come from; I know if they are normal or abnormal. I know if they merit additional attention or if they can be ignored.

column1: ESTJ	It can be difficult for me to ignore things like hunger. Even if I try to ignore it
column2: the sensation is powerful and tends to be very distracting.

column1: ESTJ	That said
column2: I am the first person to ignore pains if they're not serious and I have something on my plate that I care more about. I believe niss noted a statistic somewhere that said SJs are the types that often end up being killed off by physically-related issues later in life. We tend to ignore/put off physical problems for the sake of higher priority issues.

column1: ESTJ	Basically
column2: if the pain doesn't impede us from completing a goal
column3: we'll ignore it until we have free time to deal with it.

column2: similar to INFPs. Difference is that they have a different method and way of understanding others. column1: ESTJ	From what I can see with my dad
column2: stress causes him to get very creative in pessimistic thinking: everything will be interpreted in the worst possible way. For example
column3: our family bought lately
column4: even though second hand
column5: a very expensive vehicle. My brother arranged most of the deal and purchase
column6: but was quite surprised when he paid a part in advance and learned that there was still an extra amount VAT to be paid. He concluded that he had misunderstood the dealer
column7: especially when thinking afterwards of what the man had said. My father on the other hand (who had never talked with or seen the man)
column8: felt that the seller was trying to deceive us. When later on there seemed to be a problem with the brakes (because it had stood too long still)
column9: this idea was enforced and he was angry with my brother for not being more firm enough towards the seller. However
column10: my brother who had made the contact with the dealer knew enough to trust the man and indeed
column12: the seller paid for all the extra repairs without too much fuss. I'm not saying it's wrong to be cautious
column13: but for my dad the worst possible interpretation was the reality and he was upset towards others for not seeing this. I'm sure not all ESTJ's are this way and I should add that he is also chronicly ill and therefore more prone to stress.

ESTJ	Originally Posted by Scarlet.Black   How does your Fi effect your life? :)    My dad is an ESTJ and he goes through relationships the same way I go through sensory stimuli when I'm stressed, and he can be extremely sensitive about his values when I challenge them extensively (as in pulling out the corner stone and tearing down every counter argument, in an attempt to see where it'll take us) with logic.
ESTJ	Originally Posted by Caustic Banana   My dad is an ESTJ and he goes through relationships the same way I go through sensory stimuli when I'm stressed, and he can be extremely sensitive about his values when I challenge them extensively (as in pulling out the corner stone and tearing down every counter argument, in an attempt to see where it'll take us) with logic.    Constantly challenging someones view or value is extremely draining and unnecessary in our eyes. With Fi included, this can make us.......not be around you. We dont mind a challenge, constantly doing it is going over the line though. With inferior Fi, it can be hard to express this while someone like INFP or ISFP will express this immediately and just.......drop you. Values are not something to be logically explained; it just is and whoever doesnt like it has to deal with it. We can only explain why we value it, nothing more, nothing less. Ex: I value babies. Why? because they are cute, intelligent, full of potential, interesting, strong, adorable, and loving. When you love them, they give love in return and you know its genuine and your love will be returned. Thats it. That being said, goodluck trying to get an INFP, ISFP to share their values lol.

column1: ESTJ	So the question is kind of: how do you battle restlessness
column2: when do you experience anxiety
column3: and what are you afraid of.    For me personally:

column1: ESTJ	Restlessness - This usually happens when I'm stuck in a group setting or having to converse with people that I cannot find common ground with (Ex: differing tastes in music that I have no idea about)-- it doesn't challenge me logically/intellectually so I become really restless. I just kind of let it be-- I allow myself just to be bored if I can't leave the situation or find someone else to converse with. If I'm alone
column2: usually I'll find a friend to go do something with or do something that I enjoy alone.

column1: ESTJ	Anxiety - As rare as it is
column2: I recognize this happens when I feel like I do not have control over my emotions or something triggers a negative emotional response that I don't necessarily want to voice/talk about. But I've recognized this is just a part of life/feelings.

column1: ESTJ	Afraid of - Losing all the important people around me: family mostly. Other than that
column2: I'm not afraid of much. Perhaps heights? But I don't think that's what you mean.

ESTJ	I have been dating an ESTJ guy for a couple of times. He recently has divorced because of his wife betrayal as he told me. However
column2: I don't know the story in detail. Actually I would like to know more but he asked me to give some time and then he will explain.

column1: ESTJ	Well
column2: as an ENFJ this was a little bit difficult relationship for me
column3: actually too harsh ;) but he showed a lot of enthusiasm and I also liked him and had feelings for him so I continued. Then one day we had a heated up conversation on a topic he brought up which I felt insulted and reacted strictly and somehow emotionally that hurt him. To me it was not hurting. If he could have put himself in my shoes
column4: he would have told me far worse! Anyway... a few hours later I apologized for making him upset. He responded nicely but again sent me a video which I found again disturbing. That brought the next round of fight but this time in a passive way! He called me and I did not respond as I was really mad of him. Next day I asked him to meet and resolve the issue but this time he said it would be better to give time and meet later. Meantime he had a trip to visit his family and when he came back again there was no sign of him. I told myself I will text him for the last time and if he does not reply I will let it go. This time he replied with delay but we met and resolved most of the issues that bothered both of us. In the end he told me that he would have liked to continue this relationship but right now he is looking for a new job position which is not sure yet. Also while visiting his parents
column5: he had visited a psychologist who advised him to take a few more months of break as it is too early after his divorce to enter a new relationship. He highlighted the job issue for his reason but I personally think that the advice of the psychologist was more important to him as he said I don't want to make a mistake again. Finally he asked me to give him 4-5 month time to make things work. After that we were in contact 2-3 times for just doing some normal favors for each other. Now it has been over 5.5 month and there is no sign from him. I really am not the type of a person who starts the relationship
column6: so I don't want to call him and ask him about his status. I am just wondering that shall I assume it is over? was he some kind of polite at the time he was explaining his situation? I am really confused... ESTJs please help me in understanding him

column1: ESTJ	If I'm upset in front of someone who's not close to me

column4: and still I'd wish that they left me alone cause 'it's none of their business'.

column1: ESTJ	Having control
column2: as someone mentioned above
column3: is mandatory. I mean... I (and probably 'we' - ESTJs) have complete and utter control even when we're upset. Maybe the other ESTJs react differently
column4: I can't say
column5: but even if I'm very upset
column6: I'll get myself together quickly and remember who reacted how and did what (in reaction to my being upset) as information which I'll use somehow in the future. I gather information
column7: A LOT of detailed information about anything I care about... and use it later. Manipulation? Maybe. Strategic thinking? Probably. ESTJ trait? I guess so...

column2: and if I'm upset because of them
column3: the person can fix it by comforting me
column4: showing me that they care

column2: but I feel for me It's more of what I grew up with than what society considered traditional. is it the same for you? Do you have family traditions?    I follow no traditions. That tradition-following image probably comes from the lack of being too spontaneous (and I mean 'too'

column4: not even on Christmas
column5: Easter and other traditional holidays. Family traditions? WTF is that? Seriously

column8: I guess.      Originally Posted by Aspiringwriter   2. Do you consider yourself a private person?    Depends on what you mean when you say private. I'm private in terms of my important plans
column9: and emotions which may change a result/goal I'm going after. I'm manipulative
column10: so I'm private about what my true intentions are. For the sake of 'whatever-it-is' I can be really open
column12: and all I tell you will serve me some purpose. Of course
column14: cause I don't really need to

column1: ESTJ	The only way you can make me be open
column2: truthful
column3: etc. with you is if you are more intelligent than I am and you've proven that you care about me a lot (by giving me more intelligent solutions to my problems) - that is if you want to make an ESTJ open up. Again - that could be just me.      Originally Posted by Aspiringwriter   3. What's your biggest pet peeve in other people?    I can't stand stupid. Unintelligent. Too emotional. Especially
column4: too emotional + stupid = get TF away from me. I also can't stand people who let other people walk all over them
column5: people who don't stand up for themselves
column6: weak
column7: feeble
column8: whatever... people who only follow and never lead. All else is negotiable but being an idiot in that way towards yourself and your life is what puts me off the most in other people.      Originally Posted by Aspiringwriter   4. Are you comfortable in large groups of people? How many friends do you have? How important is family to you?    I am but I don't really care about large groups and one-on-one is often more fun because it's more meaningful. Also
column9: you can manipulate better one-on-one. Large groups are fun. One-on-one has some point. And I
column11: prefer it to have some point. Most extroverts probably like large groups because they haven't got a hidden agenda like I do. Introverts prefer one-on-one because they don't like large groups and whatever. My reasoning - I'll use either the one-on-one or the large group to my benefit. I like large groups
column13: for fun.      Originally Posted by Aspiringwriter   5. I'm ISTJ- could our types get along? I've never met any before and am curious about the dynamics.    I usually prefer extroverted people but if intelligent enough
column14: an introvert will catch my attention. However
column15: I can't stand people with no social skills
column16: or people who avoid others. I don't like it when you don't communicate at all with the shop assistants or waiters
column17: or if you can't talk to strangers (for whatever reason) because of being shy or avoiding people in general. I value social skills and I like anyone who's got better ones than mine.

column1: ESTJ	This is kind of a two-part question.

ESTJ	In what ways do you think you differ from them?

ESTJ	Originally Posted by Nightstorm   This is kind of a two-part question.
ESTJ	What are your thoughts on your ENTJ counterparts?
ESTJ	In what ways do you think you differ from them?
ESTJ	- Curious INFJ    I worked under an ENTJ in my last gig. ENTJ type 3.

ESTJ	Primary difference is he is heavily long term strategical as compared to me. When working I am thinking about short term future-- next couple of years. He's thinking more long term-- next seven to ten years.

ESTJ	He excelled at seeing the overarching strategies. He falteref at designing effective tactical steps to achieve these goals due to analysis paralysis. He started gathering information and suddenly there was never enough info to push him to make a decision. He was also terrible at focusing on the right details. Under stress he would pull out a microscope and try to control everything that didn't actually matter to achieving the goal.

ESTJ	He also had a habit of putting too much responsibility on his employees. This was good and bad: it helped every person in the office take full ownership of their work and be proactive about solving issues themselves when they arose. However
column2: it meant when real problems that required his intervention as an authority occurred he was too quick to tell an employee to take responsibility and deal with it themselves (rather than step up and get involved).

column1: ESTJ	That said
column2: he was one of the brightest men I've had the pleasure to work with. A very intelligent
column3: capable man
column4: with a lot of wisdom. We would spend hours talking after work sometimes and I'd come away feeling like I'd taken a masters class in business ownership and leadership. He has been a major positive influence on my professional life.

column1: ESTJ	Engage his Si. Remind him of his strengths where this job is concerned and the times in the past when he has used those strengths to his ability.

His job was different and he was worried that he wouldn't learn the new skills adequately. I told him that he's top in his field for a reason and his ability to learn things on his feet is amazing.I gave him examples and I told him that not only did he learn the skills he needed

column1: ESTJ	Originally Posted by DLila   Any examples of how you
column2: an individual ESTJ defy your stereotype?    the only people i hang out with are NFs. my entire close circle of friends are NFs. i cry at least once a week. i believe feelings are 100% valid. i support people relentlessly in their emotional needs + i'm super duper empathetic and considerate of people's feelings + needs. i try to see outside of my own perspective all the time. i test sometimes as an NF type because i have such a strong fi + have learned how NFs process and see the benefits of that as well. i can't process fully like that

column3: do you ever find Ne irritating? Have you ever seen it in action and liked it?    Ne in ESTJs particularly of the slightly more relaxed version is super obvious. Especially in a more casual enviorment; you can see it in ESTJ "story-time" where an ESTJ will start going on random Si/Ne tangents; ESTJs can often have a really great sense of humor and be quite funny and enjoy creativity (you don't see it as much in ESTJ work mode). I have known some ESTJs to venture into art and creative projects. I think (bad) Ne grips in ESTJs make ESTJs seem *super* paranoid. Never fun to be in the presence of an ESTJ in a non-functioning Te-Ne loop - although it's kind of hilarious. My ESTJ manager will become just completely and utterly scatterbrained
column4: paranoid by every possibility

column1: ESTJ	Every ESTJ I've known has hated my Ne (initially); but also loved it. I remember when I started working with my ESTJ manager she would tell people "man this girl asks a lot of questions". She would complain about it initially and I knew she didn't love the amount of questions I asked but at the end of day because of all my questions I would do everything right and cover all my bases (exactly why I do this). I look at every possibility and every situation from different angles so if a situatuon did come up I can react when that situation did come up. Eventually she was using me as example to other staff because I wasn't afraid to ask questions. And because of my questions I was doing everything right. ESTJs only find Ne annoying if there's no follow-through as long as you can prove your competence and it takes a long time for ESTJs to trust anyone so it's not overnight. Always expect some amount grumbles from an ESTJ though when you're talking to them with a lot of Ne (especially in a work enviorment). I've known many ESTJs to apologize for acting too harshly in the moment but don't expect it until later and probrably after you've proven yourself to them. column6: like what is really going on inside your head when you encounter smb like that.    I believe I can help. With less self-aware ESTJ's
column7: inferior Fi suppresses their own feeling based judgments and so they tend to consider that the same in others is also a weakness. It's a projection. They have spent their lives suppressing their feeling based judgements and that has given them success so it becomes a self-repeating cycle of suppression > validation - which then again gets projected to others because they had success with it. Emotions while not Jungian related in terms of psychology similarly also got repressed because repression for them reaps rewards over time ... Then comes the nature of Si where it's mostly projection of what worked for them would work for others - and since repression of emotion worked for them
column8: it'll work for someone else too. Most (if not all) ESTJ's don't have the time or the energy or even desire to understand emotions of others at all because they're so busy repressing all of that F related "stuff" in their own mind. They need to be repressed because if they're not repressed then they get in the way of achieving what they wanted to achieve. My dad is a lot like your mom in that regard. Only after turning 73 has he started somewhat exploring his emotional side
column9: but even then he'll share a few emotional things one day and then go back to his repressive state the next like nothing ever happened. Right now one of my cousins is dying of a stroke (he's only 51) and my dad has no emotion to speak of. None at all. It's clear that he's buried it so deep that it seems like it doesn't even exist - and he probably believes that it doesn't exist for him either.
